documents.content:
=== TITLE ===
31 CFR § 526.206 Exempt transactions.
=== END TITLE ===

=== DOCUMENT TEXT ===
§ 526.206 Exempt transactions.  (a)  International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The prohibitions contained in this part do not apply to any transactions that are exempt pursuant to section 203(b) of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1702(b)). (b)  Official business. The prohibitions contained in § 526.201(a) do not apply to transactions for the conduct of the official business of the United States Government by employees, grantees, or contractors thereof.
=== END DOCUMENT TEXT ===

=== COMMENTARY ===
Notes  1) APPLICABILITY OF IEEPA EXEMPTIONS  Compare 588.206 (Western Balkans Stabilization Regulations), another "exempt transactions" provision written in this style.  As discussed in at length in General Note on the Applicability of IEEPA/TWEA Exemptions in EOs and Sanctions Regulations not Specifically Mentioning Them, the non-waivable exemptions in section 203(b) of IEEPA apply even where they are not explicitly implemented in regulations, except where the prohibitions implemented are based on an authority (e.g. UNPA / FNKSR) that do not include exemptions. For the years up through the 9-29-22 publication of 553.206 (2022), OFAC had been issuing regulations making no reference to IEEPA exemptions other than the personal communications exemption.  Here, OFAC does not explicitly implement the travel and informational materials exemptions as it had in the past (see e.g. 560.210(c)), but it does, at least, explicitly state that "[t]he prohibitions contained in this part do not apply to any transactions that are exempt pursuant to section 203(b) of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, (50 U.S.C. 1702(b))."  That statement should be read in light of subsection (a), which states that the exemptions "do not apply to transactions involving property or interests in property of persons whose property and interests in property are blocked pursuant to the authority of the United Nations Participation Act". The "Note 1 to paragraph (a)" is consistent with OFAC past statements concerning the relationship of IEEPA exemptions and regulations pursuant to which persons are and are not blocked pursuant to UNPA.   2) INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS  The scope of the informational materials exemption applicable here has been interpreted identically across programs. The Research System contains over 100 guidance letters, interpretive rulings, FAQs and other documents addressing the various interpretive issues that have come up with regard to the exemption. Refer to, e.g. Examples of the "Substantive or Artistic Alteration or Enhancement" and "Fully Created and in Existence" Standards, Notes Common to the "Information or informational materials" Definitional Provision, Notable Applications of the Definition of "Information or Informational Materials" and Examples of Transactions Exempt as Incident to Underlying Informational Materials Transactions.  3) TRAVEL   a) The scope of the exemption for travel and transactions ordinarily incident thereto been interpreted identically across programs. The Research System contains a multitude of guidance letters, interpretive rulings, FAQs and other documents addressing the various interpretive issues that have come up with regard to the exemption. See Notable Examples Illustrating the scope of the travel Exemption.  4) PERSONAL COMMUNICATIONS  The Personal Communications exemption is common across programs, and interpretations of it can be found in the Research System by selecting the "Key Legal Issues" search criterion associated with the personal communications exemption. [12-23-23 UPDATE - See Case No. IA-2017-339679-1 (certain "mentoring" services provided by a non-profit over the internet through social media are exempt under the IEEPA "personal communications" exemption)].   5) DONATIONS/HUMANITARIAN  Some "Exempt transactions" provisions allow for transactions of this type. In this case, the President invoked the authority, granted under IEEPA, to decline to apply the exemption for donations.  6) TRANSACTIONS ORDINARILY INCIDENT TO EXEMPT TRANSACTIONS, GENERALLY  To the degree that a transaction is exempt from regulation as a result of an IEEPA-mandated exemption (i.e. personal communications, informational materials, travel, (and sometimes donations)), all transactions incident to the exempt transactions are also, themselves, exempt. See Notes Common to the 400-Level Interpretive Provisions Authorizing Transactions "Ordinarily Incident" to a Licensed Transaction; Transactions Incident to Others in General (System Ed. Note). This is true whether or not the underlying transaction involves a U.S. person. See General Note and Associated Matrix Pertaining to U.S. Person Engagement in Transactions Incident to Transactions by Foreign Persons (System Ed. Note).  7) OFFICIAL BUSINESS  Refer to General Note on Exemptions and General Licenses for the "Official Business" of the U.S. Government (and/or United Nations) and Employees, Contractors, or Grantees Thereof, for comments on scope of this provision.
=== END COMMENTARY ===

answer:
According to [Case No. IA-16194], OFAC’s guidance confirms that U.S. airlines generally may rely on the travel exemption for interline ticketing and baggage (ITB) and special prorate agreements (SPAs) with Iranian carriers when the agreements are directly incident to international travel to or from Iran. In that correspondence, OFAC explained that—so long as the agreements are limited to transactions ordinarily incident to arranging travel (that is, they cover services directly related to facilitating travel such as coordinating reservations, baggage handling, and ticket issuance)—they are exempt from the prohibitions of the Iranian Transactions Regulations. However, the guidance also notes that additional details (for example, whether the agreements include ancillary services, involve purely domestic travel within Iran, or include non–travel-related transactions) must be provided before a final determination is made.

It is also important to note that while the travel exemption covers arrangements directly incident to facilitating travel (including ITBs and SPAs), it does not cover transactions or services that are not directly related to the travel process. For example, if an agreement were to include services beyond simple facilitation of international travel, those components might fall outside the exemption. Additionally, OFAC’s guidance clarifies that entities designated under certain sanctions programs (such as those designated under the Global Terrorism Sanctions Regulations) may be excluded from the benefit of this exemption even if the agreements are incident to travel.

In summary, based on [Case No. IA-16194]:
 • Interline ticketing and baggage and special prorate agreements are generally exempt under the travel exemption provided they are strictly confined to activities directly incident to facilitating international travel.
 • Additional information (e.g., the nature of any ancillary services or domestic-only travel components) is needed to ensure all aspects of the agreements fall within that exemption.
 • The exemption does not apply to transactions involving entities designated under programs (such as the GTSR) that exclude such exemptions.

This answer is based on the detailed OFAC correspondence in [Case No. IA-16194].
